naics_coverage.coverage_note: 15 models across 7 NAICS sub-sectors. Trucking (4841) has highest concentration reflecting its $875B revenue, 1.6M workers, and position as the primary autonomous/AI transformation target. Warehousing (4931) is second given employment doubling and robotics adoption wave. Under-represented: air transport (481), pipeline (486), and water transport (483) -- these are either oligopolistic (harder for startups) or small-employment niches.

2026.headline: Autonomous Trucking Inflection + Warehouse Robotics Acceleration
key_events: Aurora Innovation targets 200+ driverless trucks operating by end 2026 on highway corridors
Second-generation autonomous hardware reduces costs 50%, doubles lidar range to 1,000m
Warehouse robotics adoption crosses 30% of warehouses using some form of automation
FSMA 204 enforcement expands, forcing digital cold chain tracking adoption
EV truck mandates begin affecting California fleet purchasing decisions (CARB Advanced Clean Fleets)
Digital freight brokerage penetration reaches 18-22% of total freight transactions
Federal infrastructure spending reaches peak deployment: $89.9B transit, $17B ports
2026.employment_effect: +1.0% (warehousing still adding jobs, trucking stable, transit declining)

2027_2028.headline: Mixed Fleet Reality + Last-Mile Diversification
key_events: Aurora targeting $80M run-rate by end 2027 -- first meaningful autonomous trucking revenue
Mixed human-autonomous fleets become operational reality for large carriers (10-20% autonomous miles)
Transfer hub infrastructure built on major freight corridors (I-10, I-35, I-40, I-80)
Warehouse robotics orchestration becomes standard for 3PL operations
Drone delivery BVLOS approvals expand to 15+ states, medical drone delivery reaches $1B
Driver shortage reaches 100K+ -- accelerating autonomous adoption by necessity
Micro-fulfillment deployments reach 5,000+ locations (grocery, convenience, pharmacy)
2027_2028.employment_effect: Flat to -0.5% (autonomous trucking begins displacing long-haul drivers, offset by warehouse/logistics growth)

2029_2031.headline: Autonomous Mainstreaming + Sector Restructuring
key_events: Autonomous trucks operating on 25+ highway corridors, representing 5-10% of line-haul freight miles
Truck driver demand peaks and begins structural decline (long-haul first, local/drayage last)
Warehouse employment begins declining as robotics density reaches critical mass (50%+ of tasks automated)
Cold chain fully digitized for FSMA compliance -- paper-based monitoring obsolete
Digital freight brokerage reaches 40-50% penetration, traditional phone brokers consolidated or closed
EV trucks reach 10-15% of new commercial vehicle sales, creating fleet dual-fuel management complexity
MaaS platforms achieve 15-20% adoption in major metros, integrating transit + ride-hail + bikes + scooters
Port automation reaches 30+ US terminals, reducing dwell time 30-40%
2029_2031.employment_effect: -1.5 to -3% annually (autonomous trucking displacing long-haul, warehouse robotics reducing picking/packing labor, offset by logistics management and technology roles)

sector_transformation_outlook.confidence_note: MEDIUM confidence on timeline. Autonomous trucking has historically disappointed on timelines (Aurora delayed commercial launch from 2024 to 2025). Regulatory, liability, and public acceptance factors could delay autonomous mainstreaming by 2-3 years. Warehouse robotics timeline is HIGHER confidence -- the technology is proven and labor shortage creates inexorable adoption pressure. Last-mile and drone delivery timelines are LOWER confidence -- regulatory gating makes predictions unreliable.

fear_friction_assessment.detail: Transportation has one of the highest fear-friction gaps in the economy. ECONOMIC readiness is high: the technology works (autonomous trucks are driving on public highways), the labor shortage is real and worsening, and the cost savings are massive ($0.45-0.65/mile driver cost eliminated). But PSYCHOLOGICAL readiness is low: 3.58M truck drivers (plus Teamsters union) represent concentrated political opposition, public trust in autonomous vehicles is <40%, and the cultural identity of trucking as 'last bastion of independent work' creates emotional resistance that transcends economics. The fear friction manifests as: (1) regulatory delay -- legislators in trucking-dependent states will slow autonomous deployment; (2) insurance uncertainty -- who is liable when an autonomous truck is involved in a fatality?; (3) labor action -- Teamsters have signaled willingness to strike over autonomous deployment; (4) shipper hesitation -- many shippers will not use autonomous trucks until forced by cost pressure. The friction is highest in LONG-HAUL TRUCKING (driver displacement is most direct) and lowest in WAREHOUSING (robots augment workers who cannot be hired, not replace existing workers). Net effect: economic transformation timeline of 2026-2028 is extended to 2028-2031 by fear friction.

methodology_notes.scoring_methodology: Composite = (SN*25 + FA*25 + EC*20 + TG*15 + CE*15) / 10. Categories: STRUCTURAL_WINNER >=80, FORCE_RIDER >=65, CONDITIONAL >=50, NICHE <50. CLA scores are independent of transformation scores. All TAM figures sourced from published market research with specific citations. No model received STRUCTURAL_WINNER because the sector's primary transformations (autonomous trucking, warehouse robotics) involve PHYSICAL INFRASTRUCTURE with high capital intensity, reducing CE scores below the threshold. The highest-scoring model (MC-V312-TRN-001, Autonomous Trucking Middleware, 79.0) approaches STRUCTURAL_WINNER but the capital requirements for AV integration development and the dependency on external AV deployment timelines moderate the score.
key_uncertainties: Autonomous trucking deployment timeline: Aurora guides 200+ trucks by end 2026 but has missed prior timelines
Regulatory environment: current administration may accelerate or decelerate autonomous vehicle approvals
Insurance/liability framework for autonomous vehicles remains unresolved at federal level
EV truck economics: battery costs must decline 30-40% for cost parity with diesel on long-haul routes
Warehouse employment trajectory: will robotics create net jobs (new roles) or net losses (displacement)?
Cold chain regulations: FSMA 204 enforcement rigor under current FDA leadership uncertain
